description:
I wish the DeYoung cafe was this good. You don't need to have a lot of options to have a good restaurant eating ground.

The quiche is wonderful and comes with salad. My favorite is the curry, which comes with the coconut rice. This is a great vegetarian dish, to which she could add protein if you wanted to. But it's perfect and healthy and filling.

Also delightful are the desserts! Especially the apple tart, a small round item, and when they have it the rhubarb tart, which comes in a slice.

The staff is truly wonderful and patient, and will go out of their way to help you.

Need I mention the setting? If the weather is permitting, sit on the outside patio among the olive trees and statuary. Inside can get a bit noisy with people talking, but it's pleasant as well with the light streaming in.
author: Cleo B.

description:
THE VEGGIE BURGER IS EVERYTHING. Seriously. It's a giant burger with a yummy sweet and savory slaw, delicious aioli, and toasted buns. Add avocado for an even yummier experience. It comes with this side salad dressed in a light citrus magic that is fabulous. (I have eaten this twice in one week). 

The staff here is lovely, and Jay is such a rad chef - always coming out and tending to guests with the biggest smile on her face. 

Sure, the menu items are a bit on the "pricier" side, buuuuut this is a museum practically in the middle of nowhere AND the food is amazing, thus is worth every penny.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Such a cool and delicious menu. I loved the creative  names for the different items. My friend and I had the avocado on toast and absolutely loved it. I'm not sure what the secret ingredient was, but it was the best I've had. Amazing!

I just wished that the portions were bigger, or the price lower. I was expecting high prices in a museum cafe, but found it pretty ridiculous that toast and some salad came out to $15. I doubt the portion size will leave most people full.

The staff working here wasn't the nicest I've encountered either. The atmosphere is relaxing and luminous though, with nice views to the exterior of the museum.
author: Ángela J.

description:
If you're visiting the Legion of Honor Musem, have some down time and find yourself hungry, this is a good option, as it's located downstairs inside the Museum. I was at the Museum, with some free time, in between lectures, and wandered down here for a casual (order at the counter) sit down lunch.

Interestingly, the menu changes along with the featured exhibits. For example, since Casanova spent some of his earlier years, there are a couple of Italian dishes on the menu. I ordered a vermicelli glass noodle dish with pork. It had a very strong Vietnamese slant, with a profound taste of fish sauce. In fact, if I closed my eyes, I would've sworn I was eating this dish at a Vietnamese restaurant! It was pricey, but really, really good. In fact, this was my second time enjoying this dish here. I wanted to have it one more time, before they removed it from their rotating menu.

They also serve a variety of desserts after they stop serving their full lunch menu.

There's also outdoor seating available in an outdoor garden-like setting. Only problem is those warmer days are really rare in SF, especially in this part of town.

I definitely wouldn't make a special trip to come here, as I'd say it's definitely overpriced for what it is, but I usually always do lunch here whenever I do a "museum day" here.
author: Lori N.

description:
A very nice place to get off your feet and relax while at the Museum.  Downstairs, along with restrooms, a gift store and some smaller exhibits.  We thought the menu very excellent and the food very good, but the prices are high.  But given the location, the quality of food, perhaps the prices are somewhat justified.  Out lunch, two grilled cheese sandwiches, bag of chips and two sodas was $49.65.  Now that I see that in writing, it IS very expensive.

You go through a cafeteria line with a tray.  Order, pick up your drinks and chips grab a number on a stand and then make a gallant try to find a table.  It was crowded on the weekend we were visiting.  Fortunately, some of the tables occupied by one or two people will, European style, allow you to sit with them.  Otherwise...you wait.

Impressive menu.  The grilled cheese sandwich is with mushrooms and truffles.  Pretty fancy and very flavorful but at $19 each, better be.  There are salads at $13 - 15, quiches at $13 and chicken pot pie for $14.50.  Sandwiches $12 - 19 and a hotdog is $7.50. 

But it is clean, well kept up with table clearing and the staff is very nice.  A-OK.

And if you think you can go elsewhere to eat, forget it unless you want to hike to your distant car, drive  into the surrounding area and then return?  Nope...you are a captive audience, so just bite the bullet or your truffle grilled cheese and consider it another way of supporting an excellent museum.
author: Mitch K.

description:
Enchanting museum atmosphere. Mediocre food. 

Came for the Monet exhibit. Stayed for the French cuisine. 

The outdoor dining area is beautiful. The space is kept clean. Servers are nice. Pleased to see a few water stands with cutlery and napkins.

I ordered the zaandaan entree which sounded healthy and fresh. It was a big bowl of French stew comprised of pulled pork, green beans, and topped with pickled red onion and micro greens. Perfect presentation, but, it arrived luke warm and tasted overly sweet. Didn't care for it. At $17 it was disappointing. 

Hubby got the croque monsieru. The half sandwich was tiny and looked like a regular ham sandwich. The greens were tossed in a sour, inedible orange vinaigrette. $17

I've heard the regular menu is great; and the BLT is a hit! If I come back hungry I'll check it out.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Genuinely surprised...and pleasantly so. 

This was my first experience at the Legion of Honor Cafe and the quality of the food was top notch. While the prices were a *little* on the high side, they were quite affordable when compared with other food options I've had in museums.  

Most interesting though was the menu itself; with salads, mains, deserts and beverages all of a French theme aligning with the current Monet exhibition.  

We tried the cafe because we were running late and wanted to save time; but next time we'll plan to have our meal here. I'm curious what the food will be for the "Mummies and medicine" exhibit.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Great museum cafe. Wish there were a few more options or a soup on the menu but the options they did have were varied and interesting. 
Everyone in our group was very happy with their food. We ordered spaghetti and meatballs, salmon burger and pulled pork sandwich. Everything was delicious. The chef came out to make sure we were happy with everything. She even brought my two year old son an extra meatball and a granola bar because she saw him scarfing down my husbands meatballs. 
Minus one star just because the prices are a bit high. Four entree meals, one Arnold Palmer and one bottle of Diet Coke came to $85. But the food was great and it was very convenient and comfortable. Would recommend if you are at the museum and don't want to go searching for a place and parking spot somewhere else at lunchtime.
author: Lauren Z.

description: Minus star this is. If people see in the back they would not put it in their mouth and money wise, it's expensive. Work in the kitchen food that are premade, catering standard and fully made are entirely different. This is food had been frozen overnight baked add a egg and call it your 15$ meal. Prices are high over the top, how would customers/tourists genuinely tip well to the bussers cashiers also ?managers...just unethical business standards and management is laughable. Think again or plan the trip for the museum
author: Linio F.

description: This is really just about the veggie burger.  I remember having one a few years ago and it was good, but they certainly changed it for the worse.  It tastes like falafel but with cheddar cheese melted over it, which did not go at all, and some kind of slaw on it, plus an oily mayonnaise-based spread on both sides of a mushy roll making the whole thing way too messy to eat and just gross since there was too much.  I think other items may be better, and the side salad was good, so really, just don't get the veggie burger.  Prices are high at $16.50 for the veggie burger, $17 for other burgers.
author: Dora V.

description:
Amazing food! Salad, hotdog, and boxed water came to almost $40. But - one of the best salads and best hotdogs ever experienced! The portion size was generous, and everything was delicious and flavorful. 
It's a museum cafe located downstairs in the Legion of Honor museum, so you pass through the security guards check before heading in. The decor is clean and modern, with beautiful outdoor seating in a sculpture garden. 
Some of tables and chairs have seen better days, but the food makes up for it. Plus, being at Lands End, there aren't other options for a long way
author: Ed Z.

description: The woman who runs this place is extremely rude. Came down here to do some work while a friend explored the museum. I was told I had to leave because I hadn't ordered anything. I paid for a museum ticket but apparently she's not associated with the museum in any way. Never mind that it's called the "Legion of honor cafe" and located inside the museum and everyone who goes here is only here because of the museum. The place had tons of open tables and the woman who asked me to leave was ridiculously rude about it. I would have happily ordered something had she not told me to get the f out. Horrendous customer experience.
author: Kelly V.

description:
Service was super nice especially since my husband was in motorized scooter. 
Food tasty especially triple chocolate cake
author: Ann S.

description:
The word overpriced is epitomized at this place. In fact, they should re name it Overpriced Cafe of Honor. 

No. Freaking. Joke. 

But, that being said... the salad I had here for $17+ was delicious... but hardly left me full and I had to supplement with chips and dessert to feel full, so there goes the efforts of eating healthy. 

But, ambience is great for people watching, and the service was efficient, so... 3 stars seems fair.
author: Kim D.

description:
Nice cafe to enjoy Peet's coffee - a piece of very good chocolate cake ( if you are feeling flush) and watch the people.

I watched a middle aged man grab a small champagne while his bored looking hottie escort service babe grabbed a coffee.  He was floating on air as he groped and closely attended his catch.  Proud as a barnyard rooster at his good looks and debonair presence that he believes to captivate her.  The unfolding drama of a fool caught in a web.  An artful drama in the art museum cafe.

The spinster circling her chair looking for crumbs on the seat like a dog before he lays down for a nap... clothes meticulously chosen for the occasion - very Egyptian themed and very expensive.  Will she buy me another piece of cake?  I'm sure she could buy everyone in the room a piece of cake.  She gives me a short hard glance and I look away.  I don't think anyone is getting a piece of cake from her today.
author: Steve S.

description:
Never a bad meal here, and an inspired menu that frequently adopts the theme of a featured show. On my last visit I had a "Croque Monsieur" in connection with a Degas exhibit. It was ham with melted cheese on the outside of the bread. 

The down side is the cost - $38 for the sandwich, a small side salad, a pickle, two lemonades and a slice of cake. If you're hungry at the museum you're basically a captive of the cafe, and there are worse places to be trapped, but that's a lot money.
author: Steve L.

description: I get it I'm at a remote location and I'm trapped so you get to raise the prices but even this was a bit excessive.  Then to have to food be utterly bland - waste of money.  I ordered the schnitzel cauliflower.  I ended up leaving half and I noticed the table next to me did the same thing.  The museum is amazing but the cafe was a total let down.
author: Matthew S.

description:
We get to the counter at 10:47am and woman says that they're not doing their lunch menu until 11:00am.  So we order a slice of cake for my boy.  At 10:55am my wife asks to just see the lunch menu and she says no.  Pathetic. Can't look at the menu as it's top secret until 11?

Then another couple ask her to see the menu before 11 and she shows it to them!  This is horrible customer service.
author: Anthony R.

description:
It is one of the best museum cafes we have been to. They have a limited but adequate choice. It is themed to popular exhibits, making the selection fun. 
That gives specific reviews only transient value, but we have never been disappointed.  They seem to always have quiche. One orders at the counter, gets the drinks there and a number that is used by the server to bring the entree. On cold or rainy days inside tables can be scarce around lunchtime. Service is quite fast. 
The prices are not low, but appropriate for the setting at $16-$20 for entrees, less for the quiches. There is a nice choice of wines and available in a variety of quantities, a quarter liter is just nice for a couple. 
Of course, going anywhere else is awkward since it means leaving the museum and park.
author: Gio W.

description: Prices have gone up and food quality has gone down.  After a second overpriced bland meal, I'll be going elsewhere.
author: Todd B.

description:
After checking out the Houghton Hall exhibit which you might say capitalizes on the Downton Abbey mania, we headed to the cafe to have lunch.  I saw that the cafe was offering a tea service during lunch (to go with their Houghton Hall exhibit) and, so Anglophile that I am, I chose to partake in that.  I didn't even bother to look at their regular menu.  My husband, on the other hand, chose from the regular menu and I'm so glad he did!

I ordered the White Peony tea and let it steep for a few minutes, as suggested by the server.  Sadly, the tea was not that fragrant.  It really didn't have that much of a taste.  I was really disappointed with that tea.  I probably should have ordered a different one.  My sandwiches and sweets came shortly after the tea arrived.  The sandwiches were just okay.  I have had better.  Not the same quality as The Empress Lounge at the Mandarin Oriental in DC and the Rotunda at Neiman Marcus, two of the most recent tea services I've had.  The salmon sandwich was the best out of the four.  The others were a little dry and tasteless.

As for the sweets, they came on a small pedestal server.  So cute.  The plain scone was a little dry.  My husband ate the other scone which had dried fruit in it, so I didn't get to taste that.  The poppyseed loaf was okay.  I had a small bite and gave the rest to my husband.  I also let my husband eat the slice of raisin bread because I just don't care for raisin bread.  I liked the French Macaron, the the cakes, and the muffin with blueberry cream on top.  

My husband ordered the Croque-monsieur and it was delicious!  It looked so good the way it was presented!  It had a generous amount of ham and the cheese crusted bread was so good!  He was kind enough to give me a couple of bites of his sandwich.  If you find yourself in this cafe, order that.  You won't be sorry!

We ate outdoors.  It was cloudy, but it wasn't too cold.  It's actually quieter outside too.  Just be advised though that birds, lots of them, may descend upon your table and environs as you're having lunch.  Luckily, we were done eating by the time the birds came.

Next time, I will forego the tea if it's being offered, and will stick with the sandwiches.  I am ordering that fabulous Croque-monsieur and have it all to myself!
author: Hazel C.

description:
Have eaten at Legion of Honor cafe at least 6 times because I work nearby. I would have to say that the various visits have ranged from a 3 to 4 star experience. I would round up in some occasions, but due to some inconsistencies in taste, I have to round down this time. The food is generally tasty, and includes a fair selection of vegetarian items. Also speciality items like quiches, pot pies, etc. But the last two times I ordered here, my sandwich was so heavily sauced that it became quite messy. It's also hard to overlook how expensive the items are (easily $20 for a gourmet sandwich that comes with a small salad and a beverage; $5.50 for a latte). It makes sense given that it's a museum and I'm sure that influences the cost, but expensive nonetheless. 

Other plusses include a nice outdoor seating area that has a European cafe feel to it, a clean environment, and a nice view outside.
author: Will H.

description:
Of any museum I've eaten at this one had the best food.
I had a sandwich and salad with apples named after a fashion designer and a really good crunch cake.
And like all museums. ... it was expensive!
author: Funtime P.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by my lunch at this cafe today. I ordered the red curry with vegetables and coconut rice which was tasty. The vegetables were cooked nicely with some crunch and the curry had a good flavor. The rice, if I'm not mistaken, was plain with toasted coconut flakes on top. I don't like coconut but liked it on the rice. The toasted flakes as well as the pine nuts on the curry added a nice texture. I was going to take one star off since the line was super long but the order takers were efficient, the tables were clean and my meal arrived quickly so, voilà, I added a star back.
author: Robin N.

description: Delicious food, but I cannot in good conscience give a decent rating at the prices they charge. It's one thing for a fancy restaurant that takes reservations, but a museum cafe where you've already paid an admission and families bring their kids...? $16.50 for a veggie burger and no sides. San Francisco really has become a playground for the rich.
author: Scott F.

description: Wonderful lunch before hitting the Degas and Hats exhibit!  I met the chef of my delicious curry, Jay.  She is obviously loves what she's doing and it shows in her food.  Try the veggie curry.  it was delicious and pretty to look at.
author: phillis i.

description: Until today we had never had a bad meal here.  In fact the main reason we joined the museum was so that we could get in to the Cafe without paying admission costs every time.  This place was awesome...we didn't mind paying the high cost for a meal because the quality was so good.  If today's lunch was any indication, their standards have been taken down down down.  Even the roll tasted like cardboard.  The sausage was a joke.  The roasted vegetable soup did not have roasted vegetables in it.  And, the salad was limp old boxed mixed greens.  Darn it, another place bites the dust!  I WANT MY GOOD RESTAURANT BACK, PLEASE!
author: Phillipa L.

description: While there are little options and a nice setting, this place is a complete rip off.  Two salads and a veggie burger plus two cups of coffee and a sparkling juice were $67 PLUS tip at the register.  Two hours later the dehydration from the excessive sodium is still a problem and the chicken in one salad was so salty as to be inedible.
author: Roy C.

description: Exorbitant for quality of food, even for museum cafe standards.  A pre-made, Saran-wrapped tuna sandwich was $16+ after tax with an added bonus of a surly cashier.  Additionally we asked whether there was any other food besides the sandwiches and got an abrupt shake of the head for "no".  However as we sat down with our sad sandwiches, we saw the next table eating what looked like a curry dish.  Not sure what the cashier's issue was!
author: whatever I.

description:
Of course it's expensive. It's a museum cafeteria.

But considering the quality of the food/ingredients I'm A OK with it.

We stopped in after an afternoon of gazing on Monet, Rodin, Degas among others it was time to sit and unwind. It was late afternoon and we were all starving. Thankfully the Legion of Honor Cafe was here to calm our hungry bunch down.

The line was long, but don't let this scare you off as it does move quickly. The food is delicious and made with surprising care. The beer and wine selection is small, but love the fact that they serve quality bottles of French wine.

A few highlights. The quiche(s) were amazing, the BLT among the best I have ever tasted (no joke). The pecan tart (which acted as an impromptu birthday cake) got rave reviews all around, the veggie burger looked interesting and tasty, I was tempted to order it but was too busy eating bacon products.

I'd definitly come back for a bite. The grass fed hot dog is next on my hit list.
author: Rene C.

description:
We both had the beer battered tilapia. It was delicious. The breading was crisp, the fish tasty. I don't usually like tartar sauce but this was a nice accompaniment, tangy and rich, I spread it on the yummy roasted potatoes as well.  
The salad of organic mixed baby greens was expertly dressed with a delicate and divine citrus vinaigrette.
author: Mary S.

description: I was shocked on how flavorless the appetizer was.  The black bean burger is definitely a recommended dish to try! But do not get the appetizer! It is basically a breaded and fried sticky rice and cheese ball. Not good. But the salads on the dishes are soaked with a delicious vinaigrette that is to die for!! The salmon burger was not the best. The food is very very expensive and not worth it.
author: Samantha R.

description:
First thing's first: I'm poor. Like, writer poor. Like, that wasn't a simile; I'm actually a writer and I'm writer poor. And being in such a financially dismal state of affairs, I have to maintain a restriction on where each dollar goes that's strict like a fascist regime. (That last one was a simile.)

That said, I really enjoyed my meal at Legion of Honor's Museum Cafe. Sure, my Nicoise Salad cost $14, but it was delicious, ample, and wholly satisfying. Did the price impact my existential sense of self-worth? Slightly, but then I'm eating in a museum where higher prices are a given. With good service, a fantastic menu that changes with special exhibits and outdoor seating perfect for warm days, I felt every dollar was well spent. 

Would return.
author: Keane L.

description:
Great food and elegant atmosphere!

A bit overpriced, but friendly staff and service makes up for that.

Like the de Young Cafe, this cafe has delectable food options!

I ordered the Strawberry Shortcake (OMG, not overly sweet, light spongy layers of cake, creamy frosting, and fresh plump strawberries). I also ordered a hot dog (yes, a hot dog), just for a small bite since my friends and I had eaten about an hour or two at the de Young Cafe. Though it was sunny, it was somewhat windy outside, so we opted to sit inside. 

This cafe isn't as big as the de Young Cafe, but both cafes offering good food! 

Fine art and fine food = fine experience.
author: Alex C.

description: The YSL veggie burger was the best burger I have Ever had!!!! Meat or not it was beyond superb!!!!
author: Erin P.

description:
1 star because it's as low as it can go. 2 stars because the COFFEE was surprisingly good.

prior to eating lunch at the cafeTERIA, we were joking around about buying wieners from a food truck instead -- and we should have!  do not order any food or any wine -- unless you're a fan of cold, thick, tasteless layers of once-melted oily cheese smothering bland proteins or veggies on soggy bread; dry salmon with a sour, metallic aftertaste; and wines so flat and lifeless they might've been recycled from yesterday's unfinished glasses and carafes. if that's your cup of tea, then you may also enjoy the ensuing hours of gastric distress and knowing that you've just wasted $$$ on inedible, undrinkable rot.
author: Bdash W.

description:
I was in the museum with a friend and decided to have lunch at the cafe merely for the convenience.  The menu options were very limiting (per my taste buds), so I decided to go for the BLT and an Italian soda.  It was noon on a weekday.  Consequently, it was not crowded and our food arrived promptly.  Since this was a museum cafe, I didn't have high expectation.  When my BLT arrived, I was amazed that it was probably one of the better BLT's I've had in along time.  The toasted bread was crunchy, the bacon was crispy, and the grilled tomato was hot.  It was accompanied by a lightly dressed mixed green salad.  Although it was not very substantial, it certainly satisfied me till supper.

The lunch was a nice compliment to a pleasant visit of the gallery and really made the day.  I do want to mention that our meals came to about $20 per person.  It's a bit on the steep side for a cafe.  On the other hand, when the food is good, I don't mind a few extra bucks, especially at a museum where there the only other dining option is off-site.
author: Jean T.

description: Atmosphere, tranquil for a Tuesday afternoon, no crowds and the weather was perfect in the outdoor dining area, cold water available in bottles, delicious lunch of fried fish in tempura batter, with delicious roasted potatoes and a salad (Fleur De Amor) and Peets Coffee.  The grounds are also lovely with a view of the city and bay.  After our visit of the Man Ray and Lee Miller exhibit, we went back for a tasty lemon meringue tart
author: Karen W.

description:
$15 for what amounted to a grilled cheese with mushrooms on it. C'mon. I've been to museums in many major cities and expect them to be expensive, but this place flat out exploits the fact that you're there.

The cheese on the sandwich was tasty, but it was very greasy overall. It was brought out promptly, however.
author: C. C.

description:
3.5 stars 

Not bad for a museum cafe. It's a nice, relaxing place to grab lunch at Legion of Honor. You can also get a sticker to go to the cafe if you don't want to pay admission for the general museum. 

The BLT was amazing--or maybe I was really hungry. Either way, I'd highly recommend it. It had a meyer lemon aioli and grilled tomatoes, which was a nice twist on one of my favorite sandwiches. 

Although the afternoon tea sandwiches seemed like a great deal (with smoked salmon, cucumbers and cream cheese, and curried chicken sandwiches for $12.50), the bread on all of our sandwiches was hard and stale. I'm not sure if it was just our plate or if all of them were like that, but it was a shame because otherwise they would have been quite good. 

All of the bakery items looked very tempting--they had a warm chocolate cake, fruit tarts with almond paste, etc.
author: Patti F.

description: Best veggie burger that I've found in SF so far! Also great thai iced tea. Comfortable dining room with outdoor area, too. Friendly staff.
author: Toby S.

description: I came here to get my energy up after a few hours looking around in the museum.  Since it was within a few hours of closing time, it seems that the staff was getting ready to pack it all up.  I ended up getting the $3.25 can of blood orange soda and $2.50 bag of small salt & pepper potato chips.  It got the job done but at 5x the cost of what I know I can get it anywhere else.  Definitely one of the pricier cafe's I've been to.  I should have known since the whole cafe ordering area is covered in wine bottles
author: Jeff C.

description: Best place in San Francisco to have lunch.  Love the way the menu corresponds to the exhibits.  Delicious food and quick service.
author: Diane S.

description: Crazy that we even ended up here to eat. We happen to be at Lands End hiking when my wife got hungry and wanted to get something to eat. Found a trail that led up to a road which led us to the Legion of Honor. We checked in our bag and the lady that we spoke to told us there was a cafe, so we grabbed a bite to eat. Food was good and I polished it off with a cold beer. We sat outside since the weather was amazing and had a great ambiance. You order at the counter and then seat yourself with a number to place at your table and they bring your food items out to you. Good idea to have an in house cafe since we ended up spending 4-5 hours in the museum.
author: Nathan G.

description:
Absolutely nothing vegan on the menu. Come on, just one dish: is it really that hard? The museum is so spectacular, too bad their cafe is so exclusive.

Instead of patronizing this backward cafe, I recommend bopping down the hill to Clement street -- there are some great cafes that serve vegan food.
author: Alec F.

description:
Très chic! I exclaimed after viewing the "Treasures of the Louvre" exhibit this weekend at the Legion of Honor.  It was quite fun to imagine myself in Marie Antoinette's dressing room with all of her Treasures. 

After a long walk viewing many fabulous pieces of art I was starving- "Let them eat cake" I thought to myself and set off to find some food- on the bottom floor I found the café and didn't expect much more than elevated hospital food. 

I was delighted to find that they had expected that I would think this- and have taken Museum eating to the next level, just to surprise me.

Upon walking in to the gracious cafeteria style room, the menu offered options that Marie Antoinette herself would drool over- 

Dahhhling!! There were quiches, and French style salads and sandwiches with a wide variety of champagne options enough for me to spend longer here at the café then I did at museum. 

So when in the Legion, each like the Legionnaires do! $26 for two!
author: Sarah M.

description:
We came here today to see the Impressionists on Water exhibit and it was packed!  I guess every one is like us and wanted to see the exhibit before it leaves in a few  days.

We had the BLT and the three bean soup. It was all good.  Not over the top fabulous.  Do not get the Thai iced tea. It tasted weird, watered down, or something off.  We enjoyed the strawberry shortcake for dessert.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Wonderful food specials and relaxed atmosphere spell a great alternative to going to a restaurant.  Food prices are more than reasonable for a museum cafe.  Outdoor seating is available.  Loved the queen sausage special, very euro dish.  Check out the bright red Christmas tree during the holidays!
author: Brian O.

description:
My friend and I came here for lunch recently before seeing an exhibit.  Overall, it was convenient and the food was better than I've had at a lot of museums.

I had the salmon salad, which came with a sourdough roll & butter.  I was a little disappointed because I didn't realize that it was smoked salmon, but it was OK anyway.  It was a little pricey, but that's to be expected (and worth it for the convenience when meeting a friend from out of town).  My friend really enjoyed her quiche.  Oh, I had a glass of wine and it was reasonably priced ($7).

There's a lot of seating and it's bright, so try to get a spot by the window.  On the one or two days a year that it's sunny in those parts, try to get a seat outside.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Limited choices, but the food is good and healthy. The quiche was delicious.  It's expensive, but what do you expect?  Pete's coffee, polite service.  It's a nice break during the museum visit.  The inside and outside seating places are comfortable.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
The setting and museum are outstanding.  The cafe, sadly, is overpriced with inferior food.  MY soup of the day tasted like Campbell's Vegetarian Vegetqble.  It cane with a dull role, something inexcusably in a city awash with great bread outlets.  At $7.75 it was the only affordable item on a menu of $15 sandwiches.

The cheerful staff had to ask permission to combine two andjoining tables in order to accommodate seven people.  Really?

The sister institutin , the De Young, has a nice menu and fairly tasty treats.  It is within walking distance of excellent inexpensive restaurants,   The Palace Cafe, remote from anything else, seems to yell out "gottcha ha."  What a pity.
author: Susan S.

description:
Good sandwiches, semi-decent coffee, spacious, organized, and clean.

Service is friendly enough and the menu, though limited, offers a select variety of Japanese and French influenced dishes ranging from sandwiches to salads to quiches to crepes.

Not worth the price but when you do decide to dish out the dosh, just think that you're paying not only for lunch but also for the support of the museum, and that is well worth a $12 panini.
author: Yuki M.

description:
Food: Decent food for a museum cafe. Currently offering Swedish themed food to complement Anders Zorn exhibition. Ordered open faced turkey sandwich, a BLTA, Dutch Apple pie, and a pot of jasmine tea. Will give you a refill of hot water when you order a pot of tea.

Service: Self service. Order at the counter. Take a number. Server will bring the food.

Atmosphere: bright, casual, fun.
author: Beginning P.

description:
Do Not Eat At The Legion Of Honor Museum Cafe! 
Before I start, please notice that whenever I have capitalized a word that is not usually capitalized, I am trying to do the equivalent of typing in all caps, i.e. "shouting." 

Do Not Eat At The Legion Of Honor Museum Cafe! 
As I write, I have been suffering abdominal cramps for the past 7 hours.  My belly is so distended that my ribs hurt and my back aches.  I ate a chocolate-dipped coconut macaroon between 10:45 and 11:15 a.m. at the cafe, and symptoms showed up at 3:30 p.m.  I know it must have been the macaroon because I had nothing else to eat this morning, or this afternoon until 3 p.m. - I was in the middle of my lunch when the bloating first showed up.  I have not had anything to eat since then, either. 

This is not the first time I've had a problem here.  Somewhat over a year ago, I had the quiche for lunch, and got food poisoning, which I identified as Clostridium perfringens per the UC Wellness home medicine book.  Again, the quiche was the Only thing I had eaten that day. 

I do not know whether any of the food is prepared on site - I doubt it.  The cafe's own web page indicates that it comes from a caterer.  Perhaps the food is not being transported at the proper temperature, or perhaps it is not being stored at the proper temperature on site, or perhaps a cook is not following proper hygienic practices in food preparation.  All I know is that Something Is Very Wrong. 

I agree with reviewers who have said that the food is pretentious and overpriced.  But that doesn't bother me so much - I am not a good cook, and I have the means to eat out A Lot.  However, another fault is not enough variety of choices.  I got the macaroon because there wasn't anything else that appealed to me at that time of day.  Little did I know that macaroons usually contain egg whites.  I am not allergic to eggs - far from it, I eat them Every Day.  But combined with what happened with the quiche, it seems to me that egg dishes in particular are not being handled properly at this cafe. 

If you do eat at the museum cafe, limit yourself to tea, coffee, bottled beverages, and packaged chips.  Don't trust anything else.
author: Carlisle H.

description:
First time experience.

I've been to the Legion of Honor once before, but I have never set foot inside of their cafe. This time I went with my girlfriend who wanted something to eat and have some coffee. We already had a late big breakfast, so we were wanting a dessert to share.

Of the desserts that they had to offer that day, we went ahead and got the Tiki Crunch Cake. A very yummy dessert that went well with my Cappuccino.
It was a nice day outside, so we went ahead and sat outside.
Their outdoor patio area is very nice and is a great place to sit and relax.

I'm hoping next time to try their lunch selections, so I can give more of a review.
But for this visit it was well worth it.

The only drawback is that one of the bussers was a little short with my girlfriend when she was trying to clean up after herself.
I'm guessing next time we should just leave our dirty plates on the table.
author: John S.

description:
I suppose my stomach is pretty strong because I didn't experience what a lot of people in these Yelp reviews experienced. No vomiting or diarrhea or anything like that so I suppose I can at least throw them one star, but I'm afraid that's all they get.  

I don't object to the pretentiousness of the menu, since I'm somewhat of a foodie myself, though what I do object to firstly is the choices, which are pretty limiting.  I think there's just four items on the lunch menu: some overpriced 8 dollar "tomato bisque", and then a kale salad.  It's already been scientifically proven that everybody hates kale, though restaurants are still behind the times on the trend.  Guys, that's so 2011 to late 2012. We're over kale now, and don't even think about quinoa. We like mixed greens and baby spinach. Stick to the classics.  The two other items were: a veggie burger. Just, no.   There's no point to veggie burgers; if I wanted a patty that tasted like meat, I'd eat a hamburger. Don't dress up a mixture of greens and add flavoring to it. Vegetarians: you made a point of avoiding meat, I'm sorry but you can't cheat! Just like Diet Coke.. if I wanted to drink sugar water, why would I drink syrupy water with fake sugar and tastes worse? Anyway.  The last option was something called a "Cavalier Chapman". I don't know what that means and I'm sure it's supposed to coincide with whatever dumb art they're charging people to see at the museum, but this is a very ill-conceived concoction.  I did order it because it was the only thing with meat, but the description even sounded weird.  "A mixture of beef, pork, and turkey" with some lettuce and some special sauce on some bread.  I don't need that much meat, but okay, I'll give it a day in court.  It turns out that it's this sort-of stew of meat and crunchy carrot bits slopped in between some bread with like 3 arugula leaves and some sauce.  I swear, there's no way this thing is designed by a chef.  It's made up by mental patients in cooking therapy class. Once you try to lift the sandwich, half of it spills out from the bread and all over your hands, and once you bite in to the hard, crusty bread, even more spills out on your lap.  After wiping myself off, I had to just try to eat the rest with a fork.  Okay, so the taste wasn't actually bad.  It was kind of spicy and had some other good flavors going on, including the sauce.  It's the consistency that made me very cross.  I hate the mess that it makes and I hate the chunks of carrots that weren't cooked.  Raw carrots are delicious but they're all wrong for a stew, or a stew sandwich in this case.  Plus, this sandwich was fifteen bucks plus another buck fifty for an avocado.  Throw in an orange soda and then taxes and a tip and I spent over 20 bucks for this disappointment.  

I guess my problem is that I don't know exactly what to expect from a museum cafe in terms of quality.  Usually, you can just get a pressed panini sandwich with chips or maybe a potato salad and some soup for around 3 dollars a cup.  I don't know why they need to charge as much and why they need to come up with weird menu items and then have to fail at them so badly.  Like I said, maybe there's not a common practice amongst all museums , public or private, but as long as they don't try too hard they should be a decent place to eat.  One star for Legion of Honor Cafe.
author: Alex H.

description:
A bit pricey for the amount of food you get, but it's totally worth it on a nice day. Plus there aren't a lot of other food options located nearby.

I ordered a sandwich with a side, which ran me $11. On a nice day, you can sit outside and enjoy the sunshine. The dining area is bright and modern. Service is pretty quick because you line up and pay cafeteria-style. If you're on a budget, I recommend picking up something nearby before enjoying your day at the museum or going to a concert at the theater.
author: Leslie H.

description:
I love that they theme their menus around the special exhibits. Most recently, they offered Dutch fare to go with the current Dutch and Flemish Masterworks exhibition, so imagine lots of almond-based pastries. 

I had the Quiche Lorraine, which was perfectly executed, and served hot (I'm used to museum food being served lukewarm). I tried some of my friend's sandwich, which was tofu on baguette, and the spread they used was really, really tasty. I am pretty sure that both of those options are offered year-round.

Seating is cramped and hard to find, at least on the weekend, so be prepared to share a table with other museum visitors. Despite this seating, I think the food at this cafe is better than the one at the de Young.
author: Jennifer B.

description: For museum cafes, this place is pretty great.  A nice variety of coffee/teas/other beverages, and the food menu is pretty extensive.  You also get a great view of the Legion of Honor grounds since the windows are nice and big throughout.  Perfect for unwinding after spending a morning/afternoon checking out the Legion of Honor.
author: Mel G.

description: The Legion of Honor Cafe isn't much different from most other museum cafes. The food and drinks are overpriced and neither are remarkable. I tried the BLT and it was forgettable--stale, hard bread, generic meat and old cheese do not a great sandwich make. However, there is plenty of seating so you should be able to find a place to rest your weary soul at any time.
author: Josephine L.

description:
The Legion of Honor Cafe is a wonderful place to visit for lunch even if you aren't visiting an exhibit at the museum. The cafe is located on the first floor of the museum across from the museum store. The cafe offers breakfast pastries in the morning and an assortment of soups, salads and sandwiches for lunch. The cafe also offers unique menu items themed after current exhibits. By far, my favorite thing on the menu is the BLT with meyers lemon aioli. The cafe also has some of the best iced tea in town as they brew delicious Paradise Flavored Iced Tea. 

The cafe is not only delicious but is a beautiful space. The flower arrangements and decor change often and are always seasonally themed. Outside seating is also available with a view of the Barbara Osher Sculpture Garden. It's a great place to relax with a salad and a glass of wine.
author: Alice S.

description: ZORN SALAD. Delight in a bowl! I would have prepared with less creamish dressing. It was so great though.
author: Jackie D.

description: I love legion of honor, but I can be careless about this cafe. It's way too overpriced for anything from popsicle to a bowl of soup(it was more like a bowl of broth for $8). My advice is eat something before you come to this great museum.
author: Anna H.

description:
I ordered a mushroom quiche which came with a green salad and bread.  The food was delicious, but the lack of service needs lots of improvement and the cafe manager, Rosalia needs to be replaced.  I noticed that the bread came on the plate.  I noticed that another patron had her bread roll served on a separate plate.  When I brought this to the cafe manager's attention, she was flippant and discourteous.  

The cafe is on a renewable contract through McCall's Catering.  I tried to bring this to the attention of Tom Seid, but all I got was voice mail. 

Be warned, if you are seeking a nice meal with a pleasant atmosphere, THIS IS NOT THE PLACE. THE SERVICE STAFF ARE DISCOURTEOUS AND UNPROFESSIONAL. THEY COULD NOT BE EMPLOYED ANYWHERE ELSE.
author: Nancy S.

description: I think one of the reasons I love to go to the Legion of Honor is the food at the cafe.  I have never had a bad lunch and most have been better than average.  Today I had the salmon salad - wild salmon (a nice change from farmed you usually get) with beans, squash, greens and a very nice dressing.  My friend had the quiche - always one of our favorite things.  Another friend had the BLT and was literally humming.  The art is great and so is the lunch.
author: Pat L.

description: The museum cafe is quite convenient after long hours of art viewing. The quiche was excellent. It came with a salad of mixed greens and a piece of seeded bread for $15. I wanted to try the much commented on BLT, but alas it is not available everyday. Overall, this was not the most economical cafe, but the food was great.
author: Jessica M.

description: I expected a Museum Cafe to be expensive, and the Legion of Honor did not disappoint, but the food was excellent.  Both the main dish salad and the sandwich we ordered were delicious.  The service was quick, and the courtyard was a lovely site to sit and enjoy our meal.
author: Lois Z.

description: I love coming to the Legion of Honor Cafe as a finish to a great trip whenever I come to see a special exhibit at the Legion of Honor. I enjoy the themed lunches and  even the standard fare. You walk in and order whatever you'd like at the front before sitting down with your number. The food doesn't take too long to come out -- with the exception of the first few days of a really popular special exhibit. Then the wait can be REALLY long. But it's usually worth it. I wish the prices were a little less expensive, especially because the portion sizes are along European lines (aka small) but I feel like I'm supporting the museum so it's worth it. I love the peaceful and relaxed atmosphere, especially eating outside on a sunny day.
author: Kristy C.

description:
This is a review for the pris-fix Sunday brunch only...

I went a couple Sundays back and decided to step it up a notch before the Annie Liebowitz exhibit (amazing) and try the $48 sit down brunch. Why not? I have to say, the food was actually very good. Much better than I thought it'd be. We started off with fruit salad & yogurt, eggs benedict with a side salad (awesome dressing) and finished off with Scharfenburger chocolate dip and shortbread cookies (really good). One mimosa is also included. My friend had a crab fritatta and said it was excellent.

My gripe: horrid service. Our server could not be anymore obvious about either being hungover or just bitter that she worked at a museum restaurant. She never offered coffee (I had to ask) and just had zero interest in her job. 'scool and all but doesn't want to make me step it up like that again, y'know?
author: Meredith R.

description: Quiche too salty, and believe it or not, too much bacon. Couldn't even eat the crabcake. Sweet. Undercooked. Not a lot of crab in the cake. Chunk of underripe avocado. Louvre-themed lunch. Less good than previous cafe meals. Pricey.
author: Dara H.

description:
Ok, I know this hasnt gotten tons of great reviews, but I went there recently and found out the cafe has changed management, and the food was UNBELIEVABLE. I had the most expensive french onion soup ever- $9- and it was worth every penny. Great place. Worth another try if you havent been there with the new management. Right now they have a french cuisine theme to go along with the current exhibit. 

Its a bit pricey, but think of it as vacation prices.
author: Seth M.

description:
Really, the setting and food for this cafe could not be beat!

After hearing about California born and raised head Chef David Garrison through several "in-the-know" foodies, and again through Fine Arts Magazine, I decided to give this place a try. 

Seated in the beautiful and tranquil outdoor seating area, our appetizer of salmon pate (perfectly presented in a country style mason container) with toast was delectable. 

This was followed by a very fresh salad nicoise with tuna. The green beans were crispy, the dressing, light and potato salad, perfect. This is my new standard for nicoise! 

Out came mulets et des frites. I was immediately transported to Belgium, where I last had this dish, ten years ago... The yummy broth was quickly soaked up with fresh french bread. Remarkably, the fries stayed crispy even when the dish cooled.

To ensure I was going to be accurately reporting on the caliber of cuisine at this place, I tried the chicken coq au vin. It was served with a creamy polenta. There must have been a bit of bacon in this as well. The textures of the succulent chicken, creamy grains and crisp bacon produced strong mouth watering feelings of pleasure. This was an experience worth trying in itself.

This was a food experience of pure, fresh flavors and seasonal inspiration. You should experience the food and the garden. Get a bottle of wine. Take your friends and plan to stay awhile.  If you are a foodie, ask to meet the chef, who is a true culinary artist. The word is, the menu changes often. I will be on the look out for what David Garrison creates next.
author: Jenise C.

description:
I was in the museum to see the Cartier, which an exquisite exhibition is highly recommended.

I decided to try the cafe and order there chicken Cesar salad, to go since it was a beautiful day and I wanted to eat outside in the park. To my surprise when I open the box this is what I saw 

Three small slices of chicken breast on top three slices of romaine lettuce and 6 grape tomatoes. All for the price of $15.16 I was disappointed I thought for the price I will be getting something better; I rather go to Safeway and get a box salad for $6.00
author: Vanessa L.

description: Had the fried tilapia which came with Irish russett potatoes and mesclun greens. That was delicious and the service was impeccable. i would definitely eat lunch here again.
author: Adrienne A.

description: Another AMAZING experince at the legion cafe!!! Check out the picture I posted of the shrimp salad, so good my mouth is still watering!!! I have to say since the new owners took over the food has improved by far. We always have such a great time and with the new french exhibit there (which is so beautiful) they now have french items on the menu to go with it! If you haven't been there its a must see in SF.
author: Eric F.

description: The kale salad was amazing!!! My boyfriend had the veggie burger and is usually a very picky eater, but was very impressed as well! We will absolutely go back.
author: Hanna B.

description:
2 stars for the excessively high prices for everything.  I wanted a piece of their  red velvet cake $5.00.  Give me a break, it was not that much and again $5.00?  Plezzzzzz.  .  However,  love their soups the best.  So I usually get the one size they have and ask extra bread.  They only bring you a tiny piece so ask for more bread. 

The cafe is very large and is Never crowed.  You can eat outside in the enclosed small courtyard decorated with trees.  Again, I love their plates and silverware but that does not take the sting out of their high prices for basic American food.  
Yet, those prices are to damn high.  It is a quiet place, so after you see all their wonderful at, you can rest your feet, relax and have a calming conversation with folks.
author: Vanilla C.

description: This is the anti-museum cafe. The cashier or manager was very outgoing and the food was AMAZING. Everything from the menu layout to the ambiance and pleasant outdoor patio was enjoyable.
author: Miriam B.

description: In terms of food quality, this is one of the best museum lunch spots I've seen.  The food -- whether sandwiches, soups, or salads -- is excellent.  There's a beautiful outdoor seating area if the weather is up for it.  It's not a bargain, but is in line with what museum cafes cost.  If you just want to eat there without paying to enter the museum, just mention this to the ticket agents and they'll let you into the cafe for free.
author: David C.

description:
Hubby and I were going to an exhibit at the Legion, so checked out the area for lunch.  It's pretty slim pickings.  We do like to use our credit cards instead of carrying cash, so that negated a number of restaurants in the general area.  We take public transportation so we look for restaurants on the muni routes, also.  My husband looked at the reviews for the cafe right at the Legion and we decided we would try it.
Not bad!
He ordered the fish sandwich, I had the BLT.  We got a couple bags of chips and a bottle of wine.  It was a nice day so we ate out on the patio, with the birds.  There are quite a lot of them and they do know where their food comes from... Anyway, our sandwiches were delivered to our table by one of the pleasant servers and we drank wine, ate and just thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  We will eat there again when attending a show at the Legion.
author: Carol H.

description:
So, so good. So, so expensive.

If my pesto tofu with veggies on a baguette were a few dollars cheaper ($13!), or my house granola with fruit had a lowfat yogurt option (more reasonable at $6), I'd definitely give another star. But the price/value is out of balance, so I'm sticking with three.

Your stomach will not be disappointed. Can't the say the same for your wallet.
author: Jason B.

description:
At a museum, you should expect the food to be kind of meh and overpriced. Here, the food is edible, even tasty sometimes, but the prices are just outrageous. $6 for miso soup? Give me a break...

I paid $12.50 for a bento box which was actually pretty sizable, but the rice was dry and so was the tofu on top. However, I tried some of my boyfriend's $6 miso and it was delicious! 

You end up sitting side by side with other museum-goers but they made the tables nice and wide so you don't really feel like you're in a cafeteria. The servers bring out your food and clear the tables quickly, and I like the glass water bottles they give to every table. 

And what I didn't think about until I glanced at other reviews: The over-the-top prices help support the museum, which is always a worthy cause.
author: Rachel A.

description:
What an awesome place.
Excellent food. Several vegetarian selections.
Beautiful atmosphere.
Pricey but you get what you pay for.
Hmmm...I wonder if you can get into the cafe without having to pay to get into the museum?
author: J S.

description: The highlight of my visit to the Legion of Honor is lunch at their cafe. On this visit we had BLT, Chicken sandwich, and french fries. All were excellent and I highly recommend eating here when you are at the Legion. Sometimes we drive up just to have lunch here.
author: Eric C.

description:
I was amazed that they actually have BLTs and other sandwiches priced at $12.50!  But they do and I ended up having one with a cup of tea and a cup of soup.  The whole lunch rang up to $21.92!  
They have the museum patrons over a barrel because it's the only restaurant around.  
As for the BLT.  Could they have at least cooked the bacon properly ?  I guess not because it was half raw.  It was a less then mediocre sandwich.  
Next time we'll go to one of the many restaurants on Clement or even a few blocks more out to the Cliff House.
author: Nicole N.

description: I also got very ill after eating at the Museum Cafe.  I had the albacore tuna sandwich on Saturday at noon.  By 6:00 p.m. I was in bad shape.   I'll spare you the details.  On Sunday, I was very close to going to the ER.  This is Monday and I'm just beginning to feel human.  Maybe I will be able to handle some broth today.  I've always had a cast iron stomach but this experience really did me in - big time!
author: Luana M.

description:
We arrived on a glorious Sunday, at 10:30. The Museum and Cafe were practically empty, and we started off with lattes and tea, sitting in the sun. 
In chatting with the staff , we learned that the cafe is run by a catering company.  We had such a pleasant time, we decided to return for lunch. Fantastic--- the vegetarian sandwiches were great, ( Pumpkin, grilled portabello and roasted peppers with aoli mayo on a cibata role) A classic BLT was terrific and a salad with cranberries and asiago cheese knocked my  wife out.  They made the most delicate slaw of thinly sliced carrots, Persian cucumbers and a rice wine vinegar.  )The place was decorated with artichokes, persimmons, and squashes and pumpkins... very autumnal.  We sat out side under olive trees, chatting in the sunlight, and marveling at the sheer luxury of hanging out at the Legion, instead of busy restaurant... very charming, and we will make this a Sunday ritual.
author: David B.

description: Two stars is a little harsh.They do try and the food and atmosphere are pretty good but let's face it, this is not a destination restaurant.Of course you're not here for the food , you are here for art and it's not like you can walk across the street to somewhere else .They give you well prepared veg with your sandwich and your sandwich is apt to be fresh and tasty . You can get Anchor Steam in the bottle .Nothing to complain about and you should have room for dinner.
author: John K.

description:
Feel rich for a day, or at least a lunch.  

I like eating at the cafe because it's in the museum.  I enjoy the floor-to-ceiling French doors on the outside wall.  I enjoy watching people enjoy the sunshine on the outside patio.  I enjoy looking at the lawn outside the end of this long dining room, which itself could be a gallery.  

Upon entering the cafe, it appeared that we were facing a take-out counter.  This was not the whole story, though, as the menus in our hands testified.  Ordering off the menu would rate us table service, and after we had ordered, we walked to our table with our number in hand.  

We ordered a Reuben sandwich and a Caesar salad, and carried our own diet Coke and tea to the table.  A buffet-style serving station along the inside wall provided the hot water for the tea.  The Reuben was mild, with something like a jack cheese in it, and the Caesar had large, crunchy croutons and Cardini dressing.  Even though we did not order chicken breast on the Caesar, and were not charged for it, we were served it, a gift from the Cafe and from the Universe.  

The service here seemed a little absent-minded, which was the same as my impression on previous visits.  Outside of a museum or a hotel, I'd flinch at the $26.04 price.  But that, you see, is part of the experience.  It was good to relax fearlessly, and to feel rich.
author: David D.

description: Museum cafes are typically mediocre and over priced, which is the case here as well. The cole  slaw with sandwiches was so sour I could barely eat it. I hope they read this so they can correct it. The museum which we've been going to for decades is excellent with a wonderful setting.
author: Michael H.

description:
The price is worth the 5star food.

The entire place is high class, and excellent.
author: Valerie B.

description: We went during the free admission day (sponsored by BofA), so we figured we'd splurge - we ate at the cafe.  The tofu veggie baguette was very good and the fruit bowl was better than most.  If one were to eat either at the Legion Cafe or the de Young Cafe, this one is definitely the better deal of the two, even though they are both expensive.  The portions are larger and you get free refills on coffee, so you would want to get your morning kick/afternoon pick-me-up here.
author: Jenn C.

description: Yummy BLAT (blt with avocado)... Nice snack after our visit.
author: Brenda H.

description:
DON'T DO IT!

I took my parents here for Sunday brunch today and have never been more disappointed by an experience.

We had reservations for 1:45.  We arrived at 1:35 and were informed by the too-cool-for-school maitre d' that we had to come back at 1:45.  I most certainly had an incredulous look on my face as I looked at the bountiful empty tables.  What difference does 10 minutes make?  The place is swarming with wait staff, it's not like they couldn't have handled a little group of three.  After some more attitude from the sorry dude, we retreated to the gift shop.

At exactly 1:45, we returned.  He seated us...BUT ONLY AFTER FLIPPING OPEN HIS PHONE TO CHECK THE TIME.  Makes me wonder what he would have done if it had in fact been only 1:44.  Or, God forbid, 1:46...would we have missed our reservation because we aren't anal time keepers?

Bread basket - Cheesecake Factory has better bread.  Butter - well, it's hard to mess up butter.  Fruit in a bowl - uninspired.  Mimosa - I've had better in, gasp, Laurel Heights.  I had the Florentine and the most over-seasoned salad in the world.  I wanted to wash my lettuce in my water.  The toast under my over-poached eggs was hard enough to sand a deck.  The pot de creme was mediocre.  The shortbread was okay.

The service was pretentious and sloppy.  For $53, I'd prefer not to have my dishes thrown down on the table like they didn't matter.  Then again, the waiter probably knew how crap the food was so treated it with the respect it deserved.

And as I sat there ingesting all the salt in California, I had to ask myself what the kitchen actually did.  This is going back to the "come back in 10 minutes" thing.  I would have understood if they needed to keep things spaced out for the kitchen if things had to be made to order for everyone.  But honestly, the only things the kitchen actually had to make were poached eggs (badly), a crab frittata (didn't hear anything about it), and steak (though I didn't see any coming from the kitchen).

Take your $53/head and spend it on food that's made and served with more love and care.  Like your local In-n-Out.
author: Christine C.

description:
We went for the brunch at 11 am at the Legion of Honor Cafe.  Since we arrived early (9:30 am -- JUST for the parking), we had a lot of time to browse through the Dead Sea Scrolls antiquities as well as the Women Impressionists exhibit.

What they didn't tell us over the phone was that the ticket was covered in the price of the brunch ticket (although, to be fair, this may have been my misunderstanding).  AND they didn't tell us that we had to go down to the cafe, talk to the manager, and obtain our ticket there for the exhibits.  He was very nice about it, and 5 minutes later we had a sticker that would allow us into everything.  (The organization of this brunch thing leaves a lot to be desired.)

We returned at about 10:55 am, and they seated us promptly, the first to arrive for our brunch time.  The musicians to our right started up immediately and unfortunately were much too loud for the environment.  Talking during their sets was almost impossible.

The food, however, made up for it.  I had an orange juice mimosa, which was mixed just right.  The servers, who seemed a bit young and inexperienced to be really professional, offered us coffee and tea.  I ordered the Florentine; the poached eggs were cooked just right, and the Hollandaise sauce was wonderful.  I followed that with the chocolate dish with almond whipped cream -- delicious.

It's a bit on the expensive side -- $53 each plus tip -- but it includes tickets to both exhibitions, and it's a wonderful way to enjoy the Legion of Honor and its present exhibits.  Just ask to be seated away from the musicians...
author: Linda B.

description:
The Legion of Honor Cafe is one of those places you go to impress people. HOWEVER...all of the artists displayed at the Legion probably would take of few turns in their graves because even artists wouldn't pay $5.00 for a friggin' PEANUT BUTTER and JELLY sandwich! For God's sake, bring your own food and sit outside and watch the 'starving' artists draw the beautiful surroundings. I gave this place 2 stars because it is associated with such a beautiful and wonderful museum.

By the way, David V.'s review, is typically how the cafe runs, especially on the weekends.
author: Dorothy S.

description: At first I was appalled by the prices, as I usually am at museum cafes, but actually we spent a reasonable amount for a light lunch. We split a brie baguette sandwich that came with a side of greens, a bag of chips and they have complimentary carafes of water which I appreciate. Sat outside in the sun, and had a great experience. I have to say, the de Young's cafe is better overall, but this place serves its purpose.
author: J E.

description:
Dinner service could use some help.  The poor kids waiting tables here just seemed overwhelmed and the restaurant wasn't even busy.  It took a really long time for them to come take an order and after we flagged him down he was flustered and dropped his order slips on the floor, whoops.  And when our food came out of the kitchen the servers clearly weren't sure which table to bring it to, so we just waved at them.  In their defense, at least they apologized to the next table for their food being so late.  And I forgive them for bringing our folio with our credit card in it to the wrong table, although that could have turned out badly.

Tonight we had a rare dinner at the museum as we were at the Legion for the supper club after hours exhibit (which, incidentally is really the best way to see a popular exhibit without the crowds and see a movie to boot).  One of us had the frisee salad, which, strangely enough came with a fried egg (I've only seen them poached) and the greens weren't frisee, but a leafy lettuce.  We had the fish and chips with the aioli and spicy ketchup.  Yum.  Yes $17 is pretty steep for fish and chips but it's the most convenient place to eat when visiting the Legion.   They had a fun special cocktail for the evening also.

I had a slightly better experience service at lunchtime during my last visit.  I think the servers are just much more accustomed to the lunch service system where diners order at the counter bring their number to their table so they need to practice more for the dinner events where they have to take orders and remember which table placed them.  

Note that for supper club evenings they do take reservations.
author: Don L.

description:
Sorry I don't get it.

$9.50 for a cheese and ham croissant which looked fairly ordinary.

Or did I dream that price?  I still find it hard to believe.

I would have scored it lower but it made some amends for serving Peets coffee.
author: Mike S.

description: The menu suffices for a museum and offers soups, salads, sandwiches as well as entree type items. Prices are very reasonable hovering around the $7-$8 mark. However, tucked on the bottom level, it's hard to find although once you get downstairs, the smell will waft into your nostrils leading the way.
author: Anita L.

description: Their food here is museum quality! Gourmet salads surprising for a cafe and ohhh.... their BLT's are too yummy. Surely worth going even if you're not going to the museum.
author: Lynn M.

description:
The soup (Cream of Broccoli) was runny and thin.
Coffee was good an strong, maybe it's been sitting too long?
The French Fries were AMAZING, but they had too much salt.

Expensive, as expected, for what you get.

Overall, missed the mark for me, I will pack my own lunch as I usually do going to the museum.
author: dj z.

description:
Not sure how this spot has such poor ratings?  I went for movie night on Thursday and we had dinner here prior to the movie.  Food for a museum spot was actually really good. The fries, killer!!!  We also had the wedge salad w/ bleu and the tacos.  I know this is an odd combo, yet  somehow seemed to come together beautifully.  Service was very attentive!!

Yes it was a bit expensive, but has a great view, and it is not the lame run of the mill museum cuisine.  I would eat here anytime I am at the museum!!
author: Nicole F.

description:
Went there on a Saturday afternoon while touring the facility as a potential wedding reception venue.  Since one of their catering options is the in-house Bon Appetit staff, my fiance and I sampled the food.  First plus -- the cafe has a mission to serve food from sustainable sources.  As a Green nut who works for the Sierra Club, this made me pretty happy for my own reasons.

As to the food itself -- I had an awesome salad.  I am not the type of person who normally considers a salad to be a suitable meal.  The greens were varied and fresh, the balsalmic dressing was tossed in with a light touch (not swamping the lettuce).  There was thickly cut, not too salty prosciutto mixed in (more meaty than fatty, yay!).  Also mixed in was goat cheese and some great seasonable fruit, nectarines and some plum pieces.  Excellent blend of salty and sweet.  My boyfriend had a standard chicken Caesar, which I was surprised to taste was actually garlicky and not tamed down for the masses.  They prepared it right there instead of making us get the pre-stocked ones by the register.  

Ambiance as also great, the terrace there is gorgeous on a clear day with the ocean views.  The olive trees on the terrace also make for some nice light shade.  Overall, a great cap-off to a nice museum tour!
author: Deidre B.

description: Good alcohol list albeit pricey. On a nice warm day, grab a nibble and a glass of bubbly. PERFECT!
author: Roger H.

description: It's a beautiful restaurant with big windows looking out to the Golden Gate Bridge scenery. We didn't get to eat the hot food because the kitchen was closed but we did try some prepared salads. The strawberry-yuzu dressing was refreshing and just sweet enough without being cloying. The yuzu gave a nice spicy kick. The salad was fresh and fruity with bright yellow squash and strawberries. And the desserts were really well-made. For dessert, we had an apple pie and fruit tart that had delicious crumbly and buttery crusts. I give a five for their great desserts!
author: Katherine W.

description: Service is good and visitors are nice. Weather and location both are excellent. I wish to live close enough to eat there and walk up the hill everyday. Not only a wonderful exercise with a beautiful breathtaking scenic. Oh, I paid total $13.96 for a salad without ordering drink.
author: Freya-Loki O.

description: Very small menu and no substitions because they actually "come pre-made"--gross! I expect more from a fancy museum. Don't plan on eating at the museum unless you like packaged and microwaved food.
author: Cherelyn W.

description:
So I spent Sunday having brunch at the Legion cafe and loved it!  It's a 5-course prix fixe menu for $40 with museum admission included.  I started off with a ruby red grapefruit mimosa (my new favorite mimosa now), some bread from the overflowing bread/muffin basket, a fruit salad with yogurt, and a mixed green salad before I got to the main course, a really delicious steak medium rare with top notch frites.  Then unbelievably  there was more food, some Cowgirl Creamery Mt. Tam Triple Cream cheese with Acme crostini.  Finally, I ended with a Scharffen Berger Chocolate Pot de Creme, which was the best chocolate fix I've had in months.  My brunch mates tried the other variations on the menu: smoked salmon frittata, poached egg with dandelion greens, and rhubarb tart.  It was all good and boy, were we stuffed when we were done.

On the service note, they were all very courteous despite being crazy busy.  I did have to wait a bit to deal with the check but it's okay, it was Sunday brunch.

Afterwards, my friends and I rolled on over to gawk at the overdone almost gaudy jewels in the "Masterpieces of French Jewelry" exhibition.  When done, I still think the brunch at the Legion was the gem of the day.
author: Pelle Y.

description: The outdoor seating area is a fine place to enjoy a peaceful meal on a beautiful San Francisco day (though there is no guarantee a loud kid won't b e around).  The view is beautiful and the air smells great from the sea and the trees.  The menu is simple and varied enough.   But for me the setting is the reason to go there.
author: Jennifer A.

description: can you give a place zero stars? really. I was at the museum for a concert at the theater and stopped by the cafe for a "quick" bite to eat.  it was noon on sunday. long lines and impatient guests. the cafe line barely moved. several people bailed. they were out of half of the menu; I had to settle for a PBJ and sushi tray. the cold drinks were sitting in a bucket of melted ice water. it took forever to pay. the cashier was rude. nobody asked people what they wanted. the door to the outdoor patio seating was stuck shut and alarm blazing. the patio was besieged by seagulls attacking empty food trays. my sushi was dried out and inedible. the peanut butter and jelly was good, the bread was too thick. maybe brunch seating with a reservation is the best way to go if you plan to eat there.
author: David V.

description: My friend and I ordered coffee lattes after our recent visit to this museum.  They were terrible! Tasted like a combo of bad hot chocolate and weak coffee.  ugh!
author: Margery N.

description: Had a couple of very tasty lunch items, hit the spot just right, but also hit the wallet pretty hard.
author: 'toph G.

description: Went to the Cartier exhibit today! The exhibit was wonderful as was the Beet Salad, absolutely wonderful, very colorful and tasty!
author: Beverly S.

description: Could I REALLY have spent more than $200 to take my family to brunch here? I must be nuts! It is in the basement with a view of the cafeteria and a few tree limbs through the windows. It took an hour and 10 minutes for them to bring our main dishes, and they comped us with some orange juice from a carton. The duck was tough and gamey and the french horn player in the trio was way too loud. I couldn't wait to go somewhere else and have something real to eat. *blech*
author: Boots H.

description:
The one star is for the location - the beautiful holdings of classical art in the museum.  The four missing stars are for the cafe's Sunday Brunch's missing service, missing food quality, missing ambiance, and missing value for the price.
The fixed price menu ($53) included a ticket to the museum - the only aspect with quality.  The three course meal started with fruit salad that was described on the menu with some fancy pampelmousse name.  The choice of three entrees - french toast, salmon and egg on toast, steak and fries - if priced lower would be acceptable.  They were utilitarian at best, not generously sized, and crudely prepared.  The 'fromage' dessert was a slice of cheese on a slice of bread with a dollop of jam.  
The hostess tried to compensate for the many insufficiencies in the dining experience, but there was no masking the overpriced, under-delivered sad show of a meal.
author: Anne J.

description:
We went for the 'Royal Affair' brunch today. Definitely not worth 53 USD per person. 
The atmosphere is like in a canteen as the room is shared with the museum visitors who buy a sandwich at the to-go counter. Fruity starter tasted nice, the baguette bread was already stale though.
For main course I ordered their Sirloin Steak with housemade sweet potato fries. The steak was un-cuttable and un-chewable, the fries were burnt. I had to return it but they could not offer me another steak (mine must have been bottom of the bucket). They offered me the other dish instead which was acceptable but nothing near what you would expect for that price. Desert cake was far too sweet and tasted like it was bought and not self-made.
The waiters were friendly but absolutely unexperienced. At those prices I am expecting waiters who know what they're doing and not just Sunday help-out students.
They did offer us a discount though, which was a nice gesture.
I still don't recommend spending your money there and can't wait to get our local Chinese take away for dinner tonight.
author: Alexandra D.

description: This review is based on ordering two items on a Friday afternoon. I had a flank steak plate with arugala and cranberries and it was quite good.  My companion had the fettucine, it tasted quite fresh though a bit peppery.  These two items were a bit on the expensive side but really not much more than one would expect to pay at a decent restaurant.  I was quite pleased, and would recommend ordering these two dishes.  The bread and butter was good as well.
author: Richard W.

description: GREAT BRUNCH!  Went with a couple of friends for the brunch they serve on Sunday, and it was a great experience.  The staff was very professional and curteous, the food was great, and the all you can drink Champange/Mimosa/Irish Coffee/Bloody Mary's was a fantastic way to start the day before viewing great works of art.  Typically places that have pre fixed brunch type meals can realy skimp on quality, and or service, however, my friends and I were very impressed with the entire experience.  This is certainly something I would do again, and a great way to introduce folks visiting S.F. to the Legion of Honor.
author: Sean M.

description: We came to the museum for a lazy Sunday afternoon with our infant daughter.  We had lunch at the cafe.  The weather was perfect-- one of those rare sunny coastal days with a slight breeze and a cloudless sky.  We ate outside and we enjoyed our quasi-frenchy food and wine.  Then we went to check out the Paris exhibit (which made me want to hop on a plane and check it out for myself).  We were starting to get tired so we headed back to the cafe for a little coffee pick-me-up/nursing break.  The baby was cranky and wet, so I put down two clean changing pads and attacked her wet nappy  (which, incidentally, never touched the table).  Then we settled into the sunshine for what promised to be a perfect nursing moment.  Then I noticed a woman striding purposefully towards us.  She identified herself as the manager and informed us that there were perfectly acceptable changing stations in the women's room and in the future could we please use them instead of the table where people eat because people were complaining.  At some point in her tirade our eyes started glazing over.  We nodded numbly and using all our concentration we were able to lose ourselves again into the magic of that perfect afternoon (mostly).
author: Carmen D.

description: I hadn't been to this museum cafe for several years. I was amazed at the transformation from a run of the mill cafeteria to a quality bistro. The food was very good and the atmosphere was extremely inviting. A perfect way to spend an afternoon after viewing fine art, or even after a day in the links of the nearby golf course.
author: Daniel R.

description: I would try to avoid eating here if I could. My meal here was less than satisfying. I had a $14 chicken pot pie with a side of salad. The dish looked a lot better than it tasted and bigger than it actually was. The crust was really flaky...it wasn't bad, but there wasn't enough of it. The pot pie came in a cup with a crust on the top. None on the sides or the bottom of the pot pie, just this dome on top. I don't even know if that qualifies as a pot pie anymore. The dish needed more chicken, but what was most disappointing was the liquid inside the pot pie. It didn't have a thick consistency; it wasn't even a thin gravy. All I can call it is liquid. Salty liquid. It had the consistency of a broth. That's not the way pot pie should be, at least not in my book. After I finished, I was still pretty hungry. I liked their chilled water bottles and service was pretty friendly, but I wouldn't want to eat here again.
author: summer k.

description: It's your typical museum cafe: overpriced soups, salads, sandwiches.  Not really tasty, but good enough for a quick bite to eat before heading back to the city (or wherever you would be heading back to).  It was really quiet, so it was an ideal location to do my Spanish homework.
author: Marijke D.
